Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is attributed to Joseph Goebbels, but there is no direct evidence or source provided to confirm that he actually said those words.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that intellectuals would never be converted and would always yield to the stronger, which may be a problematic assumption as it generalizes the behavior and beliefs of intellectuals.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided by the expert, stating that the specific attribution of the quote to Goebbels is incorrect and that it was a summary of his viewpoint made by a third party.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the influence and power of propaganda by stating that it is ineffective on intellectuals and should only appeal to emotions.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Goebbels always maintained that propaganda had to be truthful, as observed by the expert.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by misattributing the quote to Goebbels when it was actually written by British historian Hugh Redwald Trevor-Roper.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating biases in the claim.
